RNA sequences that are predominantly cleaved by RNaseL are U-rich. the cleavage points are typically at the 3′ end of UA or UG or UU di-nucleotides, leaving a 5′-OH and a 3′-monophosphate in the cleavage product. cellular targets of RNaseL include both ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and mRNAs. a global effect of RNaseL is observed in the form of autophagy induced through c-jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) signaling and apoptosis. the ER serves as a conduit for maturation of cellular proteins which are either secreted or destined to be associated with a membrane. a perturbation of the folding capacity can lead to an accumulation of unfolded proteins in the ER lumen, which signals an unfolded protein response. IRE1 is a type I single-pass trans-membrane protein in which, similar to what is observed with RNaseL, the N-terminal resident in the ER lumen serves as sensor and the cytosolic C-terminal as the effector. the cytosolic C-terminal segments have a serine/threonine kinase domain and a RNase domain homologous to that of RNaseL. a trans-autophosphorylation by the kinase domain allosterically activates the RNase domain.
